meta.title: Heart Sounds S3, S4 Ejection Click & OS

questions.text: A 48 year old male was found to have a heaving type of cardiac apex and grade 3 ejection systolic murmur best heard in the 2nd intercostal space on right radiating to the carotids. Which of the following is not a part of the classical triad of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Palpitation Aortic stenosis (AS) Classical triad : Option A - Angina Option B- Dyspnea Option C -Syncope

Highyeild:

Heyde's syndrome (aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding) is attributed to the presence of angiodysplasia of the gastrointestinal tract in patients with aortic stenosis. It is susceptible to serum proteases. Recent advances- MITRA clip is used in the treatment of MR. Edward Sapiens valve is used for treatment of AS

Extraedge:

Heyde's syndrome (aortic stenosis with gastrointestinal bleeding) is attributed to the presence of angiodysplasia of the gastrointestinal tract in patients with aortic stenosis. It is susceptible to serum proteases. Recent advances: MITRA clip is used in the treatment of MR. Edward Sapiens valve is used for treatment of AS

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with progressive exertional dyspnea for the past 6 months with occasional episodes of hemoptysis. She used to take monthly injections in her buttocks for some condition in her childhood which she cannot remember exactly, but she defaulted long ago. On examining this patient, which of the following findings is unlikely?

options.label: B
options.text: Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla

options.label: C
options.text: Mid diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

S3 This patient with exertional dyspnea and hemoptysis along with a history suggestive of rheumatic fever prophylaxis (monthly/3 weekly benzathine penicillin IM) suggests rheumatic heart disease , most likely combined MR+MS or isolated MS, the two most common valvular lesions in RHD. Now, S3 is caused by rapid flow of blood into the ventricle in the first rapid filling phase. In MS this rapid flow of blood is not possible, hence S3 is always absent.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : OS is present in MS with non calcified pliable valves due to sudden opening of the valve as a result of increased AV pressure gradient. Option B : This murmur is suggestive of MR involving anterior mitral leaflet, and as mentioned MR+MS is the most common valvular lesion in RHD. Option C : This murmur is suggestive of MS. Isolated MS is the second most common valvular lesion in RHD.

questions.text: You hear a low pitched sound between S2 and S4 in an apparently normal 10 year old child. Which of the following is false about this sound?

options.label: A
options.text: Best heard with the bell of the diaphragm

options.label: B
options.text: Localized to either mitral or tricuspid valve

options.label: D
options.text: Most likely physiological in this case

questions.correct_answer: C. Occurs in non compliant ventricle
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occurs in non compliant ventricle A low pitched sound between S2 and S4 in a normal child is likely to be S3, which occurs as a result of vibrations of the ventricular muscle due to rapid influx of blood into the ventricle from the atria in the first rapid filling phase . Hence if the ventricle is non compliant and stiff the vibrations will be reduced and S3 is unlikely to be heard.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : All low pitched sounds including S3 are best heard with the bell of the stethoscope Option B : S3 is usually localized over the valve or region producing it Option D : S3 is physiological in young patients and in pregnancy.

questions.text: A known case of MS under treatment comes to you for regular follow up. During auscultation, after S2, you hear a gap, followed by a high pitched sound, followed by the typical mid diastolic murmur of MS. You feel the gap has decreased from the last time you checked the patient, and order an echocardiogram to confirm your suspicions. What does the decrease in this gap indicate?

options.label: C
options.text: No relation, intensity of murmur is related to severity

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increasing severity of MS The auscultatory description of a classical case of MS given above depicts a gap after S2, followed by an opening snap (high pitched sound) due to sudden opening of the mitral valve as a result of high AV. Pressure gradient, then the murmur of MS. As the severity of MS increases, the AV pressure gradient increases, and the valve opens with a snap earlier, hence reducing the S2-OS interval. Therefore, reduction in this gap is indicative of increasing severity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Self explanatory if you’ve bothered reading the answer . Severity is increasing. Option C : Intensity of the murmur correlates poorly to severity and is influenced by a number of factors, hence it should not be used for prognostication.

questions.text: A 15 year old male presents with episodes of syncope for the past 4 years, with exertional chest pain. On auscultation, an ejection systolic murmur radiating to carotids is heard. What additional finding can you expect in auscultation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Systolic ejection click This clinical picture is suggestive of aortic stenosis, which at this age group is likely to be congenital associated with bicuspid aortic valve, and not associated with valve calcification . Therefore there will be an ejection click associated in this case, which is a low pitched sound just after S1 and before the onset of the murmur of AS. Ejection click is absent in AS associated with Calcified valves Supravalvular and subvalvular AS Functional AS associated with severe anemia, etc

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B : Tumor plop is heard in atrial myxoma, which produces a murmur similar to that of MS Option C : S3 is associated with AR not AS

questions.text: A 24 year old female presents with a history of occasional palpitations, without any history of chest pain or dyspnea. Systemic examination reveals joint hypermobility and lumbar scoliosis. On auscultation a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ehlers Danlos Syndrome This patient shows a clinical picture of musculoskeletal involvement (scoliosis + hypermobility) along with cardiac involvement. An non-ejection systolic click followed by a late systolic murmur in this context is suggestive of mitral valve prolapse , most likely in a case of Ehlers Danlos syndrome. EDS is a group of connective tissue disorders with the typical features of joint hyperextensibility.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : MR is characterized by a holosystolic murmur. Also, features of hyperextensibility would not be present. Option C : Marfan’s is associated with a typical marfanoid habitus (tall stature, long arms and stooping posture). The common cardiac lesion seen is AR (early diastolic decrescendo murmur). Option D : Although it does cause palpitations, chest pain may also be present in HOCM. It more commonly involves males and is associated with an ejection systolic murmur.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about S4?

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs in a non compliant ventricle

options.label: B
options.text: Loud S4 is heard in atrial fibrillation

questions.correct_answer: B. Loud S4 is heard in atrial fibrillation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Loud S4 is heard in atrial fibrillation S4 is caused by the rapid inflow of blood into the ventricle during the second rapid filling phase as a result of atrial contraction. It classically occurs in conditions with a stiff or non compliant ventricle, as this decreases the passive filling occurring in the first rapid filling phase and diastasis and forces the atria to kick more blood during the second rapid filling phase. For S4 to occur, effective atrial contractions must be present, hence S4 is never heard in atrial fibrillation .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : As explained above, a non compliant ventricle favors the occurrence of S4 Option C : Presence of S4 is always pathological unlike S3 which can be physiological Option D : RCM is characterized by stiff ventricles, hence S4 is heard
